+### Groups and Exclusive Groups
+

+<!--
+
+### Groups and Exclusive Groups
+
+- Use `group` or `exclusive_group` metadata to mark them
+- Can nest `CLIDataclass` to provide group help string (as docstring by default)
+- Cannot doubly nest groups or exclusive groups
+
+### Subparsers
+
+- Single nested field marked with `subcommand=True`
+- Field should be a `Union` type, all of whose variants are `ArgparseDataclass` subclasses
+- Each variant must have a name
+    - By default, this will be the kebab-case version of the class name
+    - A `command_name` class setting can override this
+- Parsed args get stored in appropriate object type
+- `subcommand` property returns the string name of the chosen subcommand
+- For `CLIDataclass`, `run` can be created automatically by delegating to the subcommand field, provided each variant is a `CLIDataclass`
+-->

-<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/sql.html#fancy_dataclass.sql.SQLDataclass"><code>SQLDataclass</code></a> mixin provides SQL <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objectâ€“relational_mapping">ORM</a> (Object-Relational Mapping) functionality to a dataclass. This uses the <a href="https://www.sqlalchemy.org">SQLAlchemy</a> library under the hood.</p>
-<p>After applying the <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/sql.html#fancy_dataclass.sql.register"><code>register</code></a> decorator to a custom dataclass, it will register a <a href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/metadata.html#sqlalchemy.schema.Table"><code>sqlalchemy.Table</code></a>, after which you can use the class to perform database <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Create,_read,_update_and_delete">CRUD</a> operations in the typical SQLAlchemy way. You can also define constraints and relationships on the tables after they are registered.</p>
-<p>Since SQLAlchemy is backend-agnostic, you can use <code>SQLDataclass</code> with many popular SQL backends such as SQLite, MySQL, and PostgreSQL.</p>
-<p>See the SQLAlchemy documentation on how to set up <a href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/engines.html">engines</a> and <a href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/orm/session_basics.html">sessions</a>.</p>
+<p>Python's <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html"><code>subprocess</code></a> module is commonly used to call other programs from within Python.</p>
+<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/subprocess.html#fancy_dataclass.subprocess.SubprocessDataclass"><code>SubprocessDataclass</code></a> mixin provides a simple wrapper for <code>subprocess.run</code> which builds up the argument list automatically from a dataclass's fields. This can be useful in at least two ways:</p>
+<ol>
+<li>Cuts down the boilerplate of handling argument names and string conversions.</li>
+<li>Can improve security if you add field validation before passing values to <code>subprocess.run</code>.</li>
+</ol>

-  <h1>Subprocess calls</h1>
+  <h1>TOML conversion</h1>
 
 <!-- markdownlint-disable MD052 -->
 
-<p>Python's <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html"><code>subprocess</code></a> module is commonly used to call other programs from within Python.</p>
-<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/subprocess.html#fancy_dataclass.subprocess.SubprocessDataclass"><code>SubprocessDataclass</code></a> mixin provides a simple wrapper for <code>subprocess.run</code> which builds up the argument list automatically from a dataclass's fields. This can be useful in at least two ways:</p>
-<ol>
-<li>Cuts down the boilerplate of handling argument names and string conversions.</li>
-<li>Can improve security if you add field validation before passing values to <code>subprocess.run</code>.</li>
-</ol>
+<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLDataclass"><code>TOMLDataclass</code></a> mixin provides automatic conversion to and from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TOML">TOML</a>. This uses the <a href="https://tomlkit.readthedocs.io"><code>tomlkit</code></a> library under the hood.</p>
+<ul>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.to_dict"><code>to_dict</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/dict.html#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass.from_dict"><code>from_dict</code></a> convert to and from Python dicts.</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.to_toml"><code>to_toml</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.from_toml"><code>from_toml</code></a> convert to and from TOML file-like objects.</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/serialize.html#fancy_dataclass.serialize.FileSerializable.save"><code>save</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/serialize.html#fancy_dataclass.serialize.FileSerializable.load"><code>load</code></a> convert to and from a TOML file-like object or path.</li>
+<li><a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.to_toml_string"><code>to_toml_string</code></a> / <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/toml.html#fancy_dataclass.toml.TOMLSerializable.from_toml_string"><code>from_toml_string</code></a> convert to and from TOML strings.</li>
+</ul>
 <h2 id="usage-example">Usage Example</h2>
-<p>Define a <code>SubprocessDataclass</code> to delegate calls to command-line programs within Python.</p>
-<div class="language-python highlight"><pre><span></span><code><span id="__span-0-1"><a id="__codelineno-0-1" name="__codelineno-0-1" href="#__codelineno-0-1"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">dataclasses</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">dataclass</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">field</span>
+<p>Define a <code>TOMLDataclass</code>.</p>
+<div class="language-python highlight"><pre><span></span><code><span id="__span-0-1"><a id="__codelineno-0-1" name="__codelineno-0-1" href="#__codelineno-0-1"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">dataclasses</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">dataclass</span>
 </span><span id="__span-0-2"><a id="__codelineno-0-2" name="__codelineno-0-2" href="#__codelineno-0-2"></a>
-</span><span id="__span-0-3"><a id="__codelineno-0-3" name="__codelineno-0-3" href="#__codelineno-0-3"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">fancy_dataclass</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">SubprocessDataclass</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-3"><a id="__codelineno-0-3" name="__codelineno-0-3" href="#__codelineno-0-3"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">fancy_dataclass</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">TOMLDataclass</span>
 </span><span id="__span-0-4"><a id="__codelineno-0-4" name="__codelineno-0-4" href="#__codelineno-0-4"></a>

-</h3>

   <div class="doc doc-contents ">
   
-      <p>Given an argument parser and a field name, configures the parser with an argument of that name.</p>
-<p>Attempts to provide reasonable default behavior based on the dataclass field name, type, default, and metadata.</p>
-<p>Subclasses may override this method to implement custom behavior.</p>
+      <p>Coerces the fields from an arbitrary object to an instance of a dataclass type.</p>
+<p>Any missing attributes will be set to the dataclass's default values.</p>
+

-<p>By default, this will simply call <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.cli.ArgparseDataclass.configure_argument"><code>configure_argument</code></a> for each dataclass field.</p>
+      <p>Applies a type function to all dataclass field types, recursively through container types.</p>
+

-      <p>Settings for <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.cli.ArgparseDataclass"><code>ArgparseDataclass</code></a> fields.</p>
-<p>Each field may define a <code>metadata</code> dict containing any of the following entries:</p>
-<ul>
-<li><code>type</code>: override the dataclass field type with a different type</li>
-<li><code>args</code>: lists the command-line arguments explicitly</li>
-<li><code>action</code>: type of action taken when the argument is encountered</li>
-<li><code>nargs</code>: number of command-line arguments (use <code>*</code> for lists, <code>+</code> for non-empty lists</li>
-<li><code>const</code>: constant value required by some action/nargs combinations</li>
-<li><code>choices</code>: list of possible inputs allowed</li>
-<li><code>help</code>: help string</li>
-<li><code>metavar</code>: name for the argument in usage messages</li>
-<li><code>group</code>: name of the argument group in which to put the argument; the group will be created if it does not already exist in the parser</li>
-<li><code>parse_exclude</code>: boolean flag indicating that the field should not be included in the parser</li>
-</ul>
-<p>Note that these line up closely with the usual options that can be passed to <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/argparse.html#argparse.ArgumentParser.add_argument"><code>ArgumentParser.add_argument</code></a>.</p>
-<p><strong>Positional arguments vs. options</strong>:</p>
-<ul>
-<li>If a field explicitly lists arguments in the <code>args</code> metadata field, the argument will be an option if the first listed argument starts with a dash, otherwise it will be a positional argument.<ul>
-<li>If it is an option but specifies no default value, it will be a required option.</li>
-</ul>
-</li>
-<li>If <code>args</code> are absent, the field will be an option if either (1) it specifies a default value, or (2) it is a boolean type; otherwise it is a positional argument.</li>
-</ul>

+      <p>Iterates through the fields of a dataclass, yielding (name, field) pairs.</p>
+<p>If the dataclass contains nested dataclasses, recursively iterates through their fields, in depth-first order.</p>
+<p>Nesting is indicated in the field names via "record path" syntax, e.g. <code>outer.middle.inner</code>.</p>

       <p>Class-level settings for the <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass"><code>DictDataclass</code></a> mixin.</p>
 <p>Subclasses of <code>DictDataclass</code> may set the following boolean flags as keyword arguments during inheritance:</p>
 <ul>
 <li><code>suppress_defaults</code>: suppress default values in its dict</li>
 <li><code>store_type</code>: store the object's type in its dict</li>
 <li><code>qualified_type</code>: fully qualify the object type's name in its dict</li>
 <li><code>flattened</code>: if <code>True</code>, <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.dict.DictDataclass"><code>DictDataclass</code></a> subfields fields will be merged together with the main fields (provided there are no name collisions); otherwise, they are nested</li>
 <li><code>validate</code>: if <code>True</code>, attempt to validate data when converting from a dict</li>
 </ul>

+  <h1>SQL persistence</h1>
 
+<!-- markdownlint-disable MD052 -->
 
+<p>The <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/sql.html#fancy_dataclass.sql.SQLDataclass"><code>SQLDataclass</code></a> mixin provides SQL <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objectâ€“relational_mapping">ORM</a> (Object-Relational Mapping) functionality to a dataclass. This uses the <a href="https://www.sqlalchemy.org">SQLAlchemy</a> library under the hood.</p>
+<p>After applying the <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="reference/sql.html#fancy_dataclass.sql.register"><code>register</code></a> decorator to a custom dataclass, it will register a <a href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/metadata.html#sqlalchemy.schema.Table"><code>sqlalchemy.Table</code></a>, after which you can use the class to perform database <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Create,_read,_update_and_delete">CRUD</a> operations in the typical SQLAlchemy way. You can also define constraints and relationships on the tables after they are registered.</p>
+<p>Since SQLAlchemy is backend-agnostic, you can use <code>SQLDataclass</code> with many popular SQL backends such as SQLite, MySQL, and PostgreSQL.</p>
+<p>See the SQLAlchemy documentation on how to set up <a href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/engines.html">engines</a> and <a href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/orm/session_basics.html">sessions</a>.</p>
+<h2 id="usage-example">Usage Example</h2>
+<p>Define a <code>SQLDataclass</code> corresponding to a SQL table.</p>
+<div class="language-python highlight"><pre><span></span><code><span id="__span-0-1"><a id="__codelineno-0-1" name="__codelineno-0-1" href="#__codelineno-0-1"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">dataclasses</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">dataclass</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">field</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-2"><a id="__codelineno-0-2" name="__codelineno-0-2" href="#__codelineno-0-2"></a>
+</span><span id="__span-0-3"><a id="__codelineno-0-3" name="__codelineno-0-3" href="#__codelineno-0-3"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sqlalchemy</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">create_engine</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-4"><a id="__codelineno-0-4" name="__codelineno-0-4" href="#__codelineno-0-4"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sqlalchemy.orm</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">sessionmaker</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-5"><a id="__codelineno-0-5" name="__codelineno-0-5" href="#__codelineno-0-5"></a>
+</span><span id="__span-0-6"><a id="__codelineno-0-6" name="__codelineno-0-6" href="#__codelineno-0-6"></a><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">fancy_dataclass.sql</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">DEFAULT_REGISTRY</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">SQLDataclass</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">register</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-7"><a id="__codelineno-0-7" name="__codelineno-0-7" href="#__codelineno-0-7"></a>
+</span><span id="__span-0-8"><a id="__codelineno-0-8" name="__codelineno-0-8" href="#__codelineno-0-8"></a>
+</span><span id="__span-0-9"><a id="__codelineno-0-9" name="__codelineno-0-9" href="#__codelineno-0-9"></a><span class="nd">@register</span><span class="p">()</span>  <span class="c1"># register dataclass as a table</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-10"><a id="__codelineno-0-10" name="__codelineno-0-10" href="#__codelineno-0-10"></a><span class="k">class</span> <span class="nc">Employee</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">SQLDataclass</span><span class="p">):</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-11"><a id="__codelineno-0-11" name="__codelineno-0-11" href="#__codelineno-0-11"></a>    <span class="n">first_name</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nb">str</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-12"><a id="__codelineno-0-12" name="__codelineno-0-12" href="#__codelineno-0-12"></a>    <span class="n">last_name</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nb">str</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-13"><a id="__codelineno-0-13" name="__codelineno-0-13" href="#__codelineno-0-13"></a>    <span class="c1"># set _id as primary key, which will auto-increment if omitted</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-14"><a id="__codelineno-0-14" name="__codelineno-0-14" href="#__codelineno-0-14"></a>    <span class="n">_id</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="nb">int</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">field</span><span class="p">(</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-15"><a id="__codelineno-0-15" name="__codelineno-0-15" href="#__codelineno-0-15"></a>        <span class="n">default</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-16"><a id="__codelineno-0-16" name="__codelineno-0-16" href="#__codelineno-0-16"></a>        <span class="n">metadata</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">&#39;column&#39;</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">&#39;primary_key&#39;</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">}}</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-17"><a id="__codelineno-0-17" name="__codelineno-0-17" href="#__codelineno-0-17"></a>    <span class="p">)</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-18"><a id="__codelineno-0-18" name="__codelineno-0-18" href="#__codelineno-0-18"></a>
+</span><span id="__span-0-19"><a id="__codelineno-0-19" name="__codelineno-0-19" href="#__codelineno-0-19"></a><span class="c1"># create sqlalchemy engine</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-20"><a id="__codelineno-0-20" name="__codelineno-0-20" href="#__codelineno-0-20"></a><span class="n">engine</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">create_engine</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;sqlite:///:memory:&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-21"><a id="__codelineno-0-21" name="__codelineno-0-21" href="#__codelineno-0-21"></a><span class="c1"># create all registered tables</span>
+</span><span id="__span-0-22"><a id="__codelineno-0-22" name="__codelineno-0-22" href="#__codelineno-0-22"></a><span class="n">DEFAULT_REGISTRY</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">metadata</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">create_all</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">engine</span><span class="p">)</span>
+</span></code></pre></div>
+<p>Create a SQLAlchemy session and populate the table.</p>
+<div class="language-python highlight"><pre><span></span><code><span id="__span-1-1"><a id="__codelineno-1-1" name="__codelineno-1-1" href="#__codelineno-1-1"></a><span class="o">&gt;&gt;&gt;</span> <span class="n">Session</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">sessionmaker</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">bind</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">engine</span><span class="p">)</span>
+</span><span id="__span-1-2"><a id="__codelineno-1-2" name="__codelineno-1-2" href="#__codelineno-1-2"></a><span class="o">&gt;&gt;&gt;</span> <span class="n">session</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Session</span><span class="p">()</span>
+</span><span id="__span-1-3"><a id="__codelineno-1-3" name="__codelineno-1-3" href="#__codelineno-1-3"></a><span class="o">&gt;&gt;&gt;</span> <span class="n">person1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Employee</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;John&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Smith&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
+</span><span id="__span-1-4"><a id="__codelineno-1-4" name="__codelineno-1-4" href="#__codelineno-1-4"></a><span class="o">&gt;&gt;&gt;</span> <span class="n">person2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Employee</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Jane&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Doe&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
+</span><span id="__span-1-5"><a id="__codelineno-1-5" name="__codelineno-1-5" href="#__codelineno-1-5"></a><span class="o">&gt;&gt;&gt;</span> <span class="n">session</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add_all</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">person1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">person2</span><span class="p">])</span>

+Define a SQLDataclass corresponding to a SQL table.
+from dataclasses import dataclass, field
+
+from sqlalchemy import create_engine
+from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker
+
+from fancy_dataclass.sql import DEFAULT_REGISTRY, SQLDataclass, register
+
+
+@register()  # register dataclass as a table
+class Employee(SQLDataclass):
+    first_name: str
+    last_name: str
+    # set _id as primary key, which will auto-increment if omitted
+    _id: int = field(
+        default=None,
+        metadata={'column': {'primary_key':True}}

+
+# create sqlalchemy engine
+engine = create_engine('sqlite:///:memory:')
+# create all registered tables
+DEFAULT_REGISTRY.metadata.create_all(engine)
+Create a SQLAlchemy session and populate the table.
+>>> Session = sessionmaker(bind=engine)
+>>> session = Session()
+>>> person1 = Employee('John', 'Smith')
+>>> person2 = Employee('Jane', 'Doe')
+>>> session.add_all([person1, person2])
+>>> session.commit()
+>>> print(session.query(Employee).all())
+[Employee(first_name='John', last_name='Smith', _id=1), Employee

       <p>Mixin class for adding some kind functionality to a dataclass.</p>
 <p>For example, this could provide features for conversion to/from JSON (<a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="json.html#fancy_dataclass.json.JSONDataclass"><code>JSONDataclass</code></a>), the ability to construct CLI argument parsers (<a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="cli.html#fancy_dataclass.cli.ArgparseDataclass"><code>ArgparseDataclass</code></a>), etc.</p>
 <p>This mixin also provides a <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.mixin.DataclassMixin.wrap_dataclass"><code>wrap_dataclass</code></a> decorator which can be used to wrap an existing dataclass type into one that provides the mixin's functionality.</p>

   <div class="doc doc-contents ">
   
       <p>When inheriting from this class, you may pass various keyword arguments after the list of base classes.</p>
 <p>If the base class has a <code>__settings_type__</code> class attribute (subclass of <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.mixin.DataclassMixinSettings"><code>DataclassMixinSettings</code></a>), that class will be instantiated with the provided arguments and stored as a <code>__settings__</code> attribute on the subclass. These settings can be used to customize the behavior of the subclass.</p>
 <p>Additionally, the mixin may set the <code>__field_settings_type__</code> class attribute to indicate the type (subclass of <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.mixin.FieldSettings"><code>FieldSettings</code></a>) that should be used for field settings, which are extracted from each field's <code>metadata</code> dict.</p>

       <p>A hook that is called after the <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/dataclasses.html#dataclasses.dataclass"><code>dataclasses.dataclass</code></a> decorator is applied to the mixin subclass.</p>
 <p>This can be used, for instance, to validate the dataclass fields at definition time.</p>
+<p>NOTE: this function should be <em>idempotent</em>, meaning it can be called multiple times with the same effect. This is because it will be called for every base class of the <code>dataclass</code>-wrapped class, which may result in duplicate calls.</p>

       <p>A dataclass backed by a SQL table using the <a href="https://www.sqlalchemy.org">sqlalchemy</a> ORM.</p>
 <p>Per-field settings can be passed into the <code>metadata</code> argument of each <code>dataclasses.field</code>. See <a class="autorefs autorefs-internal" href="#fancy_dataclass.sql.SQLDataclassFieldSettings"><code>SQLDataclassFieldSettings</code></a> for the full list of settings.</p>
 <p>All dataclass fields will correspond to SQL columns unless their metadata is marked with <code>sql=False</code>.</p>
 <p>Each field may also contain a <code>"column"</code> entry in its <code>metadata</code> dict. This will provide optional keyword arguments to be passed to sqlalchemy's <a href="https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/metadata.html#sqlalchemy.schema.Column"><code>Column</code></a> constructor.</p>
 <p>Some types are invalid for SQL columns; if such a type occurs, a <code>TypeError</code> will be raised.</p>

       <p>Gets the name of an executable to run with the appropriate arguments.</p>
 <p>By default, this obtains the name of the executable as follows:</p>
 <ol>
 <li>If the class settings specify an <code>exec</code> member, uses that.</li>
 <li>Otherwise, returns the value of the first dataclass field whose <code>exec</code> metadata flag is set to <code>True</code>, and <code>None</code> otherwise.</li>

 - *JSON/TOML conversion*: convert dataclasses to JSON/TOML files and vice versa
 - *Configuration management*: store global configurations and use them anywhere in your program
 - *SQL persistence*: define SQL tables, and save/load objects from a database
 - *CLI parsing*: parse command-line arguments and store their values in a dataclass, then use them to execute your main program logic
 - *Subprocess calls*: generate command-line arguments to be passed to another program
 
-`fancy_dataclass` borrows ideas from other excellent libraries such as [`marshmallow`](https://marshmallow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/), [`pydantic`](https://docs.pydantic.dev/latest), and [`argparse_dataclass`](https://github.com/mivade/argparse_dataclass), but it aims to be as lightweight as possible in terms of its dependencies and learning curve.
+`fancy_dataclass` borrows ideas from other excellent libraries such as [`marshmallow`](https://marshmallow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/), [`pydantic`](https://docs.pydantic.dev/latest), and [`argparse_dataclass`](https://github.com/mivade/argparse_dataclass), while aiming to be as lightweight as possible in terms of its dependencies and learning curve.
 
 ## How to install
 
 ```pip install fancy-dataclass```
 
 Requires Python 3.8 or higher.
